reviewText: Based on Russell Janey's novel, the Ben Hecht/Quentin Reynolds script for this film is sometimes sappy and often uneven, but it's also a nice sentimental story, told in flashback, by William Dunnigan (played in a somber manner by Fred McMurray), a press agent who was never a very happy guy, and is burying the woman he loved (but was never able to tell her so).The real reason to watch this film is to see Alida Valli play Joan of Arc, in a "film within a film" segment. She is luminous and incredibly beautiful, and would have made a terrific Joan. Coincidentally, the lavish "Joan of Arc" production starring Ingrid Bergman was released the same year as this film.Another reason to view "The Miracle of the Bells" is to see Frank Sinatra, skinny as a rail, in the unlikely part of a soft spoken priest; this was five years before his success in "From Here to Eternity", and he is surprisingly good, but far from great. He sings "Ever Homeward", a cappella, as he sits among the grave stones; there's a lot of gloomy aspects to the film, one of them being that the setting is a poor coal mining town...though it all has a nice pay-off.Lee J. Cobb is Marcus Harris, the film producer making "Joan of Arc", and he has the humorous moment in the film with his "I won't stand for any press agent miracles !" rant, which was funny enough to make me laugh out loud, a rarity for me.Some might say it's improbable that headlines of "Nation Mourns For Movie Star" could ever happen, especially when the "movie star" is unknown, but seeing how today's media obsesses about inconsequential stories, and runs with them for days (nay, weeks !) on end, on a slow news cycle, anything could happen.Total running time is 120 minutes.
summary: like molasses, a little slow but very sweet

reviewText: When I first started watching this story I was expecting Frank Sinatra to be the main character, but it is Fred MacMurray. I am so happy I took the time to watch it. The reaction of the townspeople and his persistence pays off to show the world his love for this woman. A good solid story with an all--star cast!

reviewText: It has been such a long time since I saw this move. My father was a coal miner in the area this movie speaks of. So I can relate to some the area it shows. It was a very good movie and story. I will pass it on to my family and watch it a few more time. It brings back many memories. I'm happy that movies like this has lasted and folks like you put them out. Thank You !Audrey

reviewText: This movie lacks the enthusiasm one would expect from such highly regarded actors.  It seemed a little odd for Fred McMurray to be cast in such a somber role; Frank Sinatra was a much better match for his character as a parish priest. While the actors did a decent job keeping the plot moving, the writers overuse of flashback sequences was a bit annoying.  Overall, the lazy plot seemed to be the culprit that proved most unworthy of the acting talent.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thank you, Olive Films, for finally releasing this RKO classic.  Maybe it's just a bunch of sentimental, hard-to-swallow tripe to some -- but, I for one just LOVE this film.  Who knows why!  And who cares!  Have waited long and hard for this title to be released.  So glad that day came, and from a quality source like Olive Films.As with other Olive Films releases, the print is above standard in quality, although not as pristine a print as with other OF titles.  Also, no trailer or extras.  Still, much better than the previous Republic Pictures video versions.

reviewText: A heartwarming movie that I would give six stars to if I could.  I saw this movie when I was a child on TV.  I still get the best feeling when I watch the moving scene of Joan of Arc.  The statutes move and I am moved.  Fred McMurray falls in love with a dead woman and I am glad.  Bring a box of tissues.
summary: It is no miracle that this is a wonderful movie

reviewText: Hollywood should stay away from religious films. This pretentious piece of baloney should be viewed for its amazing cast if for no other reason. Seeing Frank Sinatra as a priest is to marvel at Hollywood chutzpah. Absolutely amazing in a not-so-good way.

reviewText: The first time I saw "The Miracle of the Bells" was a New Year's Eve party in 1980, and man, it was a bring down. Here is a somewhat nasty Fred MacMurray mourning the loss of Valli (from "The Third Man"), who had only just completed filming her Joan of Arc movie, the movie that would have catapulted this obscure nobody into a major star, it seems, but fate would have it otherwise, since she up and died. Frank Sinatra plays against type big time as a gentle young priest. I really disliked this movie, and I bet  you would too.
